#Text=Golden Week in Japan
#Text=Golden Week is a period in Japan from 29 April to early May .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Golden Week is a popular time for holiday travel .
#Text=Despite significantly higher rates , flights , trains , and hotels are often fully booked .
#Text=Popular sites for visitors may be very crowded during these times .

#Text=Popular destinations for Japanese include Asia , Guam , Saipan , and Hawaii , and major cities on the West Coast of North America such as Los Angeles , Seattle , San Diego , San Francisco , and Vancouver , and a number of cities in Europe and Australia .
#Text=April 29 : Shōwa Day ( 昭和の日 Shōwa no Hi )
#Text=May 3 : Constitution Memorial Day ( 憲法記念日 Kenpō Kinenbi ) : celebrated in honor of the ratification of the Japanese constitution in 1947 .
#Text=May 4 : Green Day ( みどりの日 Midori no Hi ) :
#Text=It honors the environment , as Emperor Showa was a lover of nature , flowers , and plants .
#Text=May 5 : Children 's Day ( 子供の日 Kodomo no Hi ) , also known as Boys ' Day or the Feast of Banners , traditionally celebrated as Tango no Sekku ( 端午の節句 ) .
#Text=It is a festival in celebration of young men .

#Text=Towns and families often hang carp streamers outdoors to represent the presence of young men within and to wish them strength and success in life , although the day is being broadened to include daughters .
#Text=At home families also display samurai dolls that represent strength and success .
#Text=This is to pray for a healthy and successful life for the children .
#Text=Golden Week is avoided by many international travelers because of the challenges of navigating crowded transportation and attractions .
#Text=The busiest days are May 3 , when many people leave the major cities , and May 5 and 6 , when they returning home .
#Text=From 2019 , the government has proposed to extend Golden Week to include April 30 and May 1 to mark the expected abdication of the Emperor and the subsequent succession .
#Text=This would make travel impacts harder to predict .
#Text=Most offices in Japan close during Golden Week , some up to 10 days .
#Text=Make sure you have enough cash on you as you might have a hard time withdrawing money .
#Text=Outdoor festivals
#Text=During Golden Week , festivals are celebrated in nearly every Japanese city .
#Text=These may include events for viewing wisteria or azalea flowers , historical parades , or cultural celebrations .
#Text=Visit Tokyo
#Text=Many Tokyoites vacation elsewhere during Golden Week , so you 'll have shorter waits and fewer crowds at Tokyo ’s restaurants , parks , museums , and other attractions .
#Text=A Hawaiian festival takes place in Tokyo during Golden Week , and there is the Spring Grand Festival at the Meiji Shrine .
#Text=Enjoy the outdoors
#Text=The weather is typically mild during Golden Week , with comfortable outdoor temperatures .
#Text=However , flower parks may be crowded with people going to see the azaleas , wisteria , and tulips .
#Text=Travel tips
#Text=If possible , avoid traveling to Japan during Golden Week .
#Text=If you ca n't help it , consider the following tips to manage your trip :
#Text=Make your reservations early : 3-6 months in advance is recommended for Japan .
#Text=This includes reserved train seating , airline tickets , hotels , and tours .
#Text=You can activate your Japan Rail Pass up to 30 days before you plan to use it .
#Text=Once you 've activated your pass , you can make seat reservations .
#Text=Allow extra time for travel .
#Text=You may encounter long lines or delays .
#Text=Be sure to allow extra time to accommodate any
#Text=Enjoy what 's local .
#Text=One way to beat the crowds is to avoid using the highways , public transportation , and tourist attractions .
#Text=Instead , plan to pursue activities within walking distance of your accommodations .
#Text=See also
#Text=Golden Week holidays in China
